name: FRENCH DEFENSE
idea: Black prepares ...d5 to contest the center immediately. Unlike the Caro-Kann, the Bc8 is locked behind the e6 pawn - that's the price to pay! In exchange, Black gets a solid structure and a clear plan: attack the white pawn chain at its base (d4) with ...c5. The French creates unbalanced positions where both sides have clear plans - White attacks on the kingside, Black counter-attacks in the center and on the queenside.
errors_white: Not choosing a system: you must decide between e5 (Advance), exd5 (Exchange) or Nc3/Nd2 (Tarrasch/Winawer)
Ignoring ...c5: this move undermines d4, if you don't react the chain collapses
Exchanging exd5 without reason: frees the Bc8 and gives Black easy play
errors_black: Forgetting to attack the chain: ...c5 is the thematic move, without it Black is passive
Letting the Bc8 die: you must find a plan to activate it (...b6/...Ba6 or ...Qb6/...Bd7)
Playing ...f6 at the wrong moment: this move weakens e6 and can be premature
development: Play ...d5 on move 2 - that's the whole point of 1...e6
The key move! Attacks the base of the d4 chain, play it quickly
The French problem! Solutions: ...b6/...Ba6, ...Qb6/...Bd7, or sacrifice on b4
Nd7 supports ...c5 and can go to f6 or b6, Nf6 (if no Advance) attacks e4
In Winawer ...Bb4 pins the Nc3, otherwise ...Be7 solid or ...Bd6 active
Often kingside castle, but sometimes the King stays in center in Winawer

traps.name: Advance Trap
traps.desc: After 3.e5, if Black plays ...c5 4.c3 Nc6 5.Nf3 Qb6?! 6.Bd3! (not a3?? Qxb2) White is well developed. AVOID (Black): Play ...Bd7 and ...Bb5 to exchange the bad Bishop, or ...Nh6-f7.

traps.name: Winawer Trap
traps.desc: 3.Nc3 Bb4 4.e5 c5 5.a3 Bxc3+ 6.bxc3 and White has the bishop pair and aims for Qg4 attacking g7! AVOID (Black): Play ...Qc7! (defends g7) or ...Ne7 before ...Qa5.

traps.name: Exchange Trap
traps.desc: 3.exd5 exd5 seems boring but if Black is not careful: 4.Bd3 Nc6 5.c3 Bd6?! 6.Qh5! creates threats on h7 and d5. AVOID (Black): Play ...Nf6 quickly to control h5.

variants.name: Advance Variation
variants.uci: e2e4 e7e6 d2d4 d7d5 e4e5 c7c5 c2c3 b8c6 g1f3
variants.white_plan: Keep the e5-d4-c3 chain. Develop Bd3, 0-0, and attack on the kingside with Na3-c2, f4 then pawn assault.
variants.black_plan: Attack d4! ...Qb6 puts pressure, ...cxd4 cxd4 then ...Nh6-f7 and ...Be7. The Bc8 comes out via d7-b5.

variants.name: Winawer
variants.uci: e2e4 e7e6 d2d4 d7d5 b1c3 f8b4 e4e5 c7c5 a2a3 b4c3
variants.white_plan: After bxc3, damaged structure but bishop pair! Qg4 threatens g7, Bd3, Ne2 and kingside attack.
variants.black_plan: ...Qc7 defends g7, ...cxd4 cxd4 creates a white isolated pawn. Plans: ...Ne7-f5 or ...Qa5+, ...Bd7, long castle.

variants.name: Tarrasch
variants.uci: e2e4 e7e6 d2d4 d7d5 b1d2 g8f6 e4e5 f6d7 f1d3
variants.white_plan: The Nd2 avoids the ...Bb4 pin. Play c3, Ne2, 0-0 and attack with f4-f5 or Qg4.
variants.black_plan: Classic plan: ...c5, ...Nc6, ...Qb6 (pressure on b2 and d4). The Bishop comes out via ...b6/...Ba6 to exchange Bd3.
